results.title: Inside the kill box: fighting the Gulf War
results.creator_credit: Kurt Sayenga, Martha Adams and Discovery Channel
results.brief_description: Made for the Discovery Channel in America, “Inside the kill Box: Fighting the Gulf War” is an examination, strictly from an American and coalition perspective, of the strategies and weaponry that allowed a victory in Kuwait against Saddam Hussein. The Gulf war (1990-91) was considered to be the first war to be played live on television, and the graphics on display here, with tanks exploding and targets being decimated, makes one think of a video game. Features an array of interviews with various pilots, strategists, and soldiers, as well as with major players such as Dick Cheney, George Bush Snr, Norman Schwarzkopf and Colin Powell. Two interviews of particular interest are with two pilots who were tortured under captivity. Whilst the technical analysis of the war tools is interesting, there remains a pro-America sentiment that disallows any semblance of a balanced perspective.

results.title: Inside the Australian ballet
results.creator_credit: Bob Hardie, Matt Dow and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Inside the Australian ballet examines the people behind the Australian Ballet Company. Consisting of 68 dancers, performing over 180 shows a year, the company is one of the hardest working in the world. With interviews throughout of some of the company’s top dancers (past and present), this documentary illustrates the hardship and dedication demanded from all dancers involved. The documentary looks at some of the artistic achievements of the Company, the artistic process itself, psychological motivations, physical injury and psychological health and frames this in terms of career management and personal aspirations. Featured artists: Steven Heathcote, Miranda Coney, David McAllister, Justine Summers, Lisa Bolte, Matthew Trent, Nicole Rhodes, Geon Van Der Wyst, Lindy Wills, Daryl Brandwood, Shane Placentino, Sarah Peace, Jason Duff. With excerpts from the following productions: Bella Figura, Mirror Mirror, Coppelia, The Vertiginous Thrill of Exactitude. Narrated by Rod Young.

results.title: Inside the atom
results.creator_credit: Jack Olsen, Sydney Newman and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: The work of scientists at the Canadian Atomic Research Centre at Chalk River, Ontario. Includes a brief explanation of atomic theory, the splitting of the atom and chain reactions. Considers atomic energy as a potential source of a new industrial revolution and mentions the present use of radioactive isotopes for the treatment of cancer and also for agricultural research. Shows research work being done to develop atomic energy as a source of industrial power.

results.title: Inside Newfoundland
results.creator_credit: Roger Morin, Sydney Newman and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Canada’s tenth province—its people, its resources, its way of life. The camera shows us St. John’s, the capital city; Cornerbrook, pulp and paper center; and Bell Island with its iron mine. The greatest wealth of Newfoundland is her people, and a visit with Fred Greeley, inshore fisherman and his family, introduces us to our fellow Canadians. Finally the importance of Newfoundland’s airports is stressed, and we visit Gander, where international air travellers come and go from the four corners of the globe.

results.title: Inside Magoo
results.creator_credit: John F. Becker, Stephen Bosustow, American Cancer Society and United Productions of America
results.brief_description: A highly entertaining and informative educational film combining both animation and live-action explaining the seven danger signals of cancer. Underlines the importance of regular medical check-ups to guard your health. Stresses the need for early diagnosis before cancer has spread throughout the body. Featuring Jim Backus in the role of Mr Magoo.

results.title: Insecurities
results.creator_credit: Beth Taylor, Susan Cornish and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
Insecurities is a snapshot of Sydney in 2004, focusing on the psychological impact of the threat of terrorism on Sydneysiders and Sydney’s public spaces.
The film explores fear, safety, security, racism and patriotism through the eyes of its subjects, asking important questions along the way: “What effects does fear, on a large scale, have on people? Do we make judgements in a state of fear that we might otherwise not make?”

results.title: Insects: how to recognise them
results.brief_description: Compares similarities and differences among insects in major groups. Differentiates between insects and other animals and shows the developmental stages through which insects pass from egg to adult. Shows parts of insects and briefly describes their functions. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.
